title: Explain the JavaScript Event Loop
description: What is the event loop in JavaScript? How do macrotasks and microtasks interact? Provide examples of execution order and common pitfalls.

blocks.text:
The **event loop** is the heart of JavaScriptâ€™s concurrency model. It coordinates execution between the **call stack**, **microtask queue** (Promises, `queueMicrotask`), and **macrotask queue** (`setTimeout`, `setInterval`, I/O, DOM events).

1ï¸âƒ£ **Call Stack:** Executes synchronous code line-by-line.
2ï¸âƒ£ **Microtasks:** Queued after the current call stack clears (high priority).
3ï¸âƒ£ **Macrotasks:** Executed one at a time, after microtasks finish.

Microtasks always run before the next macrotask â€” this is why Promise callbacks fire before any `setTimeout` callbacks, even if both are queued in the same tick.

- `A` and `E` run synchronously.
- Promise callbacks (microtasks) run next: `C`, `D`.
- Then the next macrotask (timer) executes: `B`.

Microtasks can schedule more microtasks, so heavy chaining (like nested Promises) can **starve rendering** by never yielding back to the macrotask queue.

**In Node.js**, the event loop is divided into phases:
- **timers** â†’ **pending callbacks** â†’ **idle/prepare** â†’ **poll** â†’ **check** â†’ **close callbacks**.
Microtasks (Promises) are drained after each phase, making them slightly different from browsers.

**Best Practices:**
- Use microtasks for lightweight, next-tick logic (`Promise.resolve()`).
- Use macrotasks for deferring heavy or UI-blocking operations (`setTimeout`, `MessageChannel`).
- To prevent jank: break long-running operations into smaller tasks so the browser can render in between.
